question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Find the number of solutions to the equation
\[\frac{1}{(7 - x)(1 + x)(1 - x)} + \frac{3x^2 - 18x - 22}{(x^2 - 1)(x - 7)} + \frac{3}{x - 2} = \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)}.\]
ground_truth:
We can move the $\frac{3}{x - 2}$ to the right-hand side.  We can also combine the first two fractions, to get
\begin{align*}
\frac{3x^2 - 18x - 21}{(x - 1)(x + 1)(x - 7)} &= \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} - \frac{3}{x - 2} \\
&= \frac{3 - 3(x - 1)}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= \frac{6 - 3x}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= \frac{3(2 - x)}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= -\frac{3}{x - 1}.
\end{align*}Note that $3x^2 - 18x - 21$ factors as $3(x + 1)(x - 7),$ so
\[\frac{3(x + 1)(x - 7)}{(x - 1)(x + 1)(x - 7)} = -\frac{3}{x - 1}.\]This simplifies to
\[\frac{3}{x - 1} = -\frac{3}{x - 1}.\]This can never occur, so the number of solutions is $\boxed{0}.$

question:
To solve the equation
\[\frac{1}{(7 - x)(1 + x)(1 - x)} + \frac{3x^2 - 18x - 22}{(x^2 - 1)(x - 7)} + \frac{3}{x - 2} = \frac{3}{(x - 1)(x - 2)}\]
we first find the common denominator.  The common denominator is $(7-x)(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)$.  Then the equation becomes
\[ \frac{(x-1)(x+1)}{(7-x)(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)} + \frac{(3x^2 - 18x - 22)(x-2)}{(x^2 - 1)(x-7)(x-2)} + \frac{3(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)}{(x-2)(x-1)(x+1)(x-7)} = \frac{3(x-7)}{(x-1)(x-2)(x-7)(x+1)} \]
\[ \frac{(x-1)(x+1)}{(7-x)(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)} + \frac{(3x^2 - 18x - 22)(x-2)}{(x-1)(x+1)(x-7)(x-2)} + \frac{3(x^2-1)(x-2)}{(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)(x-7)} = \frac{3(x-7)}{(x-1)(x-2)(x-7)(x+1)} \]
\[ \frac{x^2-1}{(7-x)(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)} + \frac{3x^3 - 6x^2 - 18x^2 + 36x - 22x + 44}{(x-1)(x+1)(x-7)(x-2)} + \frac{3x^2 - 6}{(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)(x-7)} = \frac{3x-21}{(x-1)(x-2)(x-7)(x+1)} \]
\[ \frac{x^2-1}{(7-x)(x^2-1)(x-2)} + \frac{3x^3 - 24x^2 + 14x + 44}{(x^2-1)(x-7)(x-2)} + \frac{3x^3 - 6}{(x-1)(x+1)(x-2)(x-7)} = \frac{3x-21}{(x^2-1)(x-2)(x-7)} \]
The denominator is always nonzero.
\[ x^2 - 1 + 3x^3 - 24x^2 + 14x + 44 + 3x^3 - 6 = 3x - 21 \]
\[ 6x^3 - 23x^2 + 14x + 57 = 3x - 21 \]
\[ 6x^3 - 23x^2 + 11x + 78 = 0 \]
Trying $x = 3$, we get $6 \cdot 27 - 23 \cdot 9 + 11 \cdot 3 + 78 = 162 - 207 + 33 + 78 = 66 \neq 0$. Trying $x = -3$, we get $6(-27) - 23(9) + 11(-3) + 78 = -162 - 207 - 33 + 78 = -224 \neq 0$.

By rational root theorem, the possible rational roots are $\pm 1, \pm 3, \pm 7, \pm 13, \pm 21, \pm 39, \pm 78, \pm 2 \cdot \text{etc}$. 
Final Answer: $\boxed{3}$
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'

&= \frac{3 - 3(x - 1)}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\
&= \frac{6 - 3x}{(x - 1)(x - 2)} \\

&= -\frac{3}{x - 1}.
\end{align*}Note that $3x^2 - 18x - 21$ factors as $3(x + 1)(x - 7),$ so
